prompt:
INDEX PRODUCT PATTERN ANALYSIS

OBSERVED:
- k5 = k2 × k3 (indices 2,3 → product 5×? no)
- k12 = k8 × 12 - 5 (index 12 appears in formula!)

HYPOTHESIS: Sometimes the INDEX itself appears in the formula.

CHECK:
1. k7 = ? × 7 + ? → 76/7 = 10.86 (not clean)
2. k8 = ? × 8 + ? → 224/8 = 28 = k8/8 ✓ (28 is integer!)
3. k9 = ? × 9 + ? → 467/9 = 51.89 (not clean)
4. k11 = ? × 11 + ? → 1155/11 = 105 (integer!)
5. k12 = ? × 12 + ? → 2683/12 = 223.58... but k8×12-5=2683

So k8 = 28×8 and k11 = 105×11

Is there a pattern where k_n = f(n) × n + g(n)?

Calculate f(n) for each key.

Thus final answer.</think>We will show that in some of the “key‐products” one may write a key Kₙ in the form

  Kₙ = n · f(n) + g(n)

with f(n) an integer (and g(n) the “leftover”). In our puzzle the keys are numbered by their “index” and sometimes one finds that a key is given as a product of two other keys. For example, we are told that

  K₅ = K₂ · K₃.

A closer look at several of the keys reveals that in some cases the index divides the key evenly so that f(n) turns out to be an integer. (In other cases the quotient is non‐integral.) In our list we have, for example,

  K₇ = 76, K₈ = 224, K₉ = 467, K₁₁ = 1155, and also
  K₁₂ = 2683 (which may be written in “mixed form” as K₁₂ = 12·223 + 7 or even, since K₈ = 224, as K₁₂ = 224·12 – 5).

Let us see what happens when we try to write the keys in the form

  Kₙ = n · f(n) + g(n).

In particular, if the quotient is an integer then f(n) is “visible.” (One may think of f(n) as a sort of secondary “index‐function”.) In our list we have:

1. For key 7:
  K₇ = 76.
Dividing by 7 gives
  76/7 ≈ 10.857… 
which is not an integer. (So in the form n·f(n)+g(n) the “factor” f(7) would be non‐integral.)

2. For key 8:
  K₈ = 224.
Dividing by 8 gives
  224/8 = 28 exactly.
That is, we may write
  K₈ = 8 · 28 + 0,
so that in this case f(8) = 28.

3. For key 9:
  K₉ = 467.
Dividing by 9 gives
  467/9 ≈ 51.89… 
which is not an integer. (Again, f(9) would be non‐integral.)

4. For key 11:
  K₁₁ = 1155.
Dividing by 11 gives
  1155/11 = 105 exactly.
That is,
  K₁₁ = 11 · 105 + 0,
so that here f(11) = 105.

Also note that key 12 (which equals 2683) does not divide evenly by 12; however, it has the alternative representation
  K₁₂ = K₈ · 12 – 5.
That is, even though 2683/12 is not an integer, one may “see” the number 224 (which is K₈) playing a role in its formation.

A few observations:
• In our list the only keys for which the division by the index gives an integer are K₈ and K₁₁.
• Moreover, 28 = 8·3.5 but more suggestively it is the 7th triangular number (since 1 + 2 + … + 7 = 28) and 105 is the 14th triangular number (because 1+2+…+14 = 105).
  That is, f(8)=T₇ and f(11)=T₁₄.

Thus one acceptable answer to the question “Calculate f(n) for each key” is as follows:

– For K₇: 76/7 ≈ 10.857… (so no integer factor f(7))
– For K₈: 224/8 = 28 → f(8)=28
– For K₉: 467/9 ≈ 51.89… (no integer factor)
– For K₁₁: 1155/11 = 105 → f(11)=105

Any answer which shows that when the index “appears explicitly” in a key’s formula it is multiplied by an integer – here f(8)=28 and f(11)=105 (with these numbers being triangular numbers) – is correct.

This is one acceptable way to state the final answer.
